abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: This study aimed to translate and validate the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy – Head & Neck (FACT-HN) in a Serbian-speaking population, assessing its psychometric properties and utility in evaluating the quality of life in head and neck cancer patients. The research focuses on determining the translated questionnaire’s reliability, validity, and cultural relevance. A total of 106 Serbian-speaking head and neck cancer patients completed the translated FACT-HN, along with other validated instruments, including the EORTC QLQ-C30, EORTC QLQ-HN43, CES-D, and GAD-7. The translation followed a standard internationally accepted procedure. Psychometric analyses were conducted using confirmatory and exploratory factor analysis, Pearson correlations, and reliability measures such as Cronbach’s alpha and intraclass correlation coefficients. The Serbian version of the FACT-HN showed excellent internal consistency across all subscales, with Cronbach’s alpha ranging from 0.70 to 0.89. Confirmatory factor analysis confirmed the five-factor structure. Strong correlations were observed between the FACT-HN and other validated QoL measures, particularly with the EORTC QLQ-C30 and EORTC QLQ-HN43. Convergent validity was satisfactory for all components except the Social Well-Being component. The Serbian version of the FACT-HN is a valid and reliable tool for assessing the quality of life in head and neck cancer patients. It provides a comprehensive assessment of physical, social, emotional, and functional well-being, making it valuable for clinical and research applications in Serbian-speaking populations. Further research is needed to assess its sensitivity to longitudinal treatment-related changes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Head and neck cancer (HNC) encompasses a group of malignancies that arise in the oral cavity, pharynx, larynx, paranasal sinuses, and salivary glands. Globally, HNC represents a significant public health concern, with an estimated 930,000 new cases and approximately 460,000 deaths annually
1
. The incidence and mortality rates of HNC vary widely across different regions, largely due to variations in risk factors such as tobacco and alcohol use, as well as human papillomavirus (HPV) and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infections
2
. The complex anatomy and essential functions associated with the head and neck region mean that HNC and its treatment often lead to profound impacts on patients’ quality of life (QoL). These include difficulties in speech, swallowing, and breathing, along with disfigurement and psychosocial distress. Additionally, the economic burden of HNC is substantial, encompassing direct medical costs, loss of productivity, and long-term care requirements
3
.

In oncology, patient-reported outcomes (PROs) have become integral in assessing the impact of disease and treatment from the patient’s perspective. PROs provide a holistic view of a patient’s health status and treatment efficacy, which can guide clinical decision-making and improve patient-centered care
4
. Furthermore, PROs can aid in assessing the symptom burden of cancer and its treatments, which can be quite severe and multifaceted. Notably, patients undergoing chemotherapy or radiotherapy for HNC may experience a range of side effects such as fatigue, pain, xerostomia, dysphagia, and emotional distress
5
. By capturing these experiences through PROs, healthcare providers can gain a more holistic understanding of the patient’s condition. Furthermore, incorporating PROs into clinical trials provides a more complete picture of how treatments affect patients’ QoL, which is critical for regulatory decisions and informing patients and clinicians about the potential benefits and risks of new therapies
6
. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and other regulatory bodies often require the inclusion of PROs in trials to assess the patient experience comprehensively
6
.

The Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Head & Neck (FACT-HN) questionnaire is one of the most widely used tools for assessing QoL in HNC patients. It provides a robust measure of physical, emotional, social, and functional well-being, as well as specifically tailored questions addressing the challenges faced by this patient population. As a specific PRO, the FACT-HN addresses the unique symptoms and concerns associated with HNC, such as difficulties with eating, speaking, and facial appearance
7
. The validity and reliability of such instruments are critical for ensuring accurate assessment and meaningful clinical insights. Additionally, accurate translation and cultural adaptation of PRO instruments are vital to maintaining their validity across different populations. This process ensures the instrument is linguistically and culturally appropriate for the target population. According to Beaton et al., the process involves several steps, including forward translation, backward translation, and pre-testing, to ensure conceptual equivalence rather than mere linguistic translation
8
. These steps are crucial to preserve the instrument’s psychometric properties, such as reliability and validity.

Validity refers to the degree to which an instrument measures what it purports to measure. There are several types of validity to consider, including content validity, construct validity, and criterion-related validity
9
.

Previously, the FACT-HN has undergone extensive validation in its original English version, demonstrating strong psychometric properties
10
. Additionally, the FACT-HN has been translated, validated, and, in some instances, culturally adapted into Malayalam, Sudanese Arabic, Chinese, Traditional Chinese, Urdu, Malaysian, Spanish, and French
11 , 12 , 13 , 14 , 15 , 16 , 17 – 18
.
This study aims to translate and validate the FACT-HN in a Serbian-speaking population.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The study was conducted at the University Clinical Center of Serbia, Clinic for Otorhinolaryngology and Maxillofacial Surgery, and the University of Dental Medicine, Department of Maxillofacial Surgery from January 2023 to June 2024. The study was approved by the Ethics Committee of the University of Belgrade Faculty of Medicine (No.17/I-36).

The study included 106 consecutive patients at least 18 years of age diagnosed with HNC localized within the larynx, pharynx, or oral cavity. Inclusion criteria were histopathologically confirmed HNC, the patient’s ability to read and write the Serbian language, and completed informed consent to participate in the study. Of the 107 screened patients, one was excluded due to an intellectual disability, which prevented them from completing the questionnaire.

All enrolled patients were given a packet of questionnaires to complete. The packet consisted of the translated FACT-HN questionnaire and previously validated and translated versions of the European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) Quality of Life core questionnaire (EORTC QLQ-C-30), EORTC Head and Neck Module (EORTC QLQ-HN43) questionnaire, Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D) questionnaire, and the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 (GAD-7) questionnaire.

sec.title: Functional assessment of cancer therapy – head & neck (FACT-HN)
sec.p:
The Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy – Head & Neck (FACT-HN) is a validated instrument employed to evaluate the QoL in patients with HNC
7
. For this study, the FACT-HN questionnaire was meticulously translated into Serbian. It comprises 39 items divided into five subscales: Physical Well-Being (PWB), Social/Family Well-Being (SWB), Emotional Well-Being (EWB), Functional Well-Being (FWB), and Additional Concerns (HNCS). Each item is rated on a 5-point Likert scale: “not at all,” “a little,” “somewhat,” “quite a bit,” and “very much,” with scores ranging from 0 to 4, respectively.

To maintain consistency where higher scores reflect better QoL, certain negatively phrased items are reverse-scored. This involves inverting the scores (e.g., 0 becomes 4, 1 becomes 3, etc.). The items subject to reverse scoring, derived by subtracting the item response from 4, are as follows: PWB (items GP1-GP7), EWB (items GE1,GE3-GE6), and HNCS (items HN2, HN3, HN6, and HN12).

The scoring methodology involves calculating the sum of item scores within each subscale, and applying reverse scoring as necessary. Subscale scores are then aggregated to produce a total score, with higher totals indicating superior QoL. The total FACT-HN score ranges from 0 to 148, where up to 40 points are derived from the HNCS subscale, 28 points from PWB, SWB, and FWB subscales, and 24 from the EWB subscale. FACT-G score ranges from 0 to 108 and is derived from the sum of PWB, SWB, EWB, and FWB subscale scores. Similarly the FACT-HN Trial Outcome Index (TOI) is derived from the sum of the PWB, FWB, and HNCS subscale scores. In instances of missing data, subscale scores can be prorated, provided that at least 50% of the items in the subscale have been completed. Prorating is achieved by calculating the mean of the completed items and multiplying it by the total number of items in the subscale
19
. This rigorous scoring process ensures a comprehensive assessment of QoL in HNC patients, facilitating a detailed evaluation of treatment impacts and patient well-being.

sec.title: European organization for research and treatment of cancer quality of life questionnaire (EORTC QLQ)
sec.p:
The EORTC QLQ is a globally recognized instrument for assessing QoL in cancer patients. It includes a core questionnaire (EORTC QLQ-C30) of 30 items spanning global health status, functional scales (physical, role, cognitive, emotional, and social functioning), and symptom scales/items (fatigue, nausea and vomiting, pain, dyspnea, insomnia, appetite loss, constipation, diarrhea, and financial difficulties)
20
. This study utilized the Serbian version of the EORTC QLQ-C30, previously validated
21
. Items are scored on a 4-point Likert scale from 1 (“not at all”) to 4 (“very much”), with the global health status/QoL scale scored from 1 (“very poor”) to 7 (“excellent”). Scores are transformed to a 0-100 scale, where higher scores on functional scales denote better functioning and higher scores on symptom scales indicate more severe symptoms.

The EORTC QLQ-HN43 is a supplementary module specifically for HNC patients
22
. It encompasses 43 items addressing symptoms and issues pertinent to HNC, such as pain, swallowing, senses (taste/smell), speech, social eating, social contact, sexuality, teeth, mouth opening, dry mouth, sticky saliva, coughing, and feeling ill. The Serbian version of the EORTC QLQ-HN43 used in this study has been previously validated
21
. Items are scored on a 4-point Likert scale and transformed to a 0-100 scale
22 , 23
.

sec.title: Center for epidemiologic studies depression scale (CES-D)
sec.p:
The CES-D is a well-established screening tool for depressive symptoms in the general population. It comprises 20 items evaluating depressive feelings and behaviors over the past week. Responses are scored on a four-point scale ranging from 0 (“rarely or none of the time”) to 3 (“most or all of the time”). The total score, ranging from 0 to 60, is calculated by summing individual item scores, with higher scores indicating more severe depressive symptoms. A score of 16 or above suggests clinically significant depression
24
. The CES-D has been translated and validated in Serbian, ensuring its reliability for assessing depressive symptoms in our patient cohort
25
.

sec.title: Generalized anxiety disorder-7 (GAD-7)
sec.p:
The GAD-7 is a concise, self-reported questionnaire used to screen for generalized anxiety disorder and evaluate its severity. It consists of seven items, each depicting a symptom of anxiety. Patients rate the frequency of being bothered by each symptom over the past two weeks on a scale from 0 (“not at all”) to 3 (“nearly every day”). The total score ranges from 0 to 21, with higher scores indicating greater anxiety severity. Scores of 5, 10, and 15 are considered cut-off points for mild, moderate, and severe anxiety, respectively
26
. The GAD-7 has been translated into Serbian and validated for clinical and research use
27
.

sec.title: Translation procedure
sec.p: The FACT-HN questionnaire was translated into Serbian following the standard FACIT group translation methodology and internationally accepted methods for cross-cultural adaptation and questionnaire validation. Initially, two independent translators translated the content of the questionnaires from English to Serbian. Then, a third translator compared the original English questionnaire with the two versions in Serbian. Following this, a fourth independent translator translated the Serbian versions back into English. The project team responsible for the translation assessed this reverse translation. Moreover, a panel of clinical experts provided feedback on the appropriateness of the initial and reverse translations.

sec.title: Statistical methodology
sec.p:
Results are presented as count (%), mean ± standard deviation, or median (25th-75th percentile) depending on data type and distribution. The data distribution was assessed using Kolmogorov-Smirnov test and visual methods (histograms and Q-Q plots). Non-parametric methods were applied for non-normally distributed data. Pearson correlation was used to assess the correlation between variables. Internal consistency and test-retest reliability were evaluated to assess the reliability of the questionnaire. Cronbach’s alpha coefficient and intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) were used to evaluate the internal reliability and test-retest reliability, respectively. Cronbach’s alpha values ≥ 0.70 were considered significant. An ICC > 0.9 was considered excellent, > 0.8 acceptable, > 0.6 weak, and ≤ 0.6 non-existent
28
. Confirmatory and exploratory factor analysis was utilized to assess construct validity utilizing principle component analysis with varimax rotation. Confirmatory factor analysis was conducted to validate the 5-factor structure of a FACT-HN questionnaire. All p-values less than 0.05 were considered significant. All data was analyzed using SPSS 29.0 (IBM Corp. Released 2022. IBM SPSS Statistics for Windows, Version 29.0. Armonk, NY: IBM Corp.).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
The FACT-HN PRO, previously translated into many languages, has demonstrated that most of the translated subscales consistently measure the same constructs, as evidenced by their high internal consistency coefficients. Interestingly, these translated versions often perform better than the original English version
10
.

Additionally, men are at a higher risk of developing HNC compared to women
29
. Our study sample had a similar gender distribution (percentage of males 73.6%); however, there is a bias toward planocellular cancer in our sample (85.3%). Considering that Serbia is classified as an upper-middle-income country, as of recent classifications by international organizations like the World Bank
30
, the validity of the responses is significantly higher in our study because the vast majority of patients had a high school education, unlike in other studies where this was a problem when it comes to filling out the questionnaire
14 , 16
.

When examining our participants’ socio-demographic and clinical characteristics, the majority were male and married, educated at the high school level, complementing other cohorts’ characteristics in other studies
31 , 32
. Approximately a third of our participants currently engage in smoking, and approximately half of the participants had previously smoked, consistent with a well-known significant role in the development of specific types of head and neck malignancies
31
. Even though more than half of our participants consumed alcohol, it was previously shown that alcohol consumption showed inconsistent results in terms of the development of planocellular carcinomas of the head and neck
31
.

The majority of our patients presented with a primary, predominantly planocellular cancer, specifically localized in the larynx, at stages II and III. Planocellular carcinoma of the head and neck region is the most prevalent type of cancer and appears to be the most researched HNC in terms of overall well-being and QoL in different domains
12 , 31 , 32
However, the specific location of this cancer varies in different studies, with oral localization being the most commonly observed
12 , 15 , 16 , 30
Finally, the vast majority of noted studies had patients who presented with advanced stages of these cancers (stage III and above)
21 , 22 , 24 , 25 – 26
.

Firstly, our subjects exhibited no problem understanding the questions and completing the questionnaire despite the high number of items. Additionally, an optional question, GS7 (sexual QoL), was answered by a limited number of participants and, therefore, was excluded from the factor analysis. However, when including it in the reliability analysis, the omission of the item did not yield any significant change in Cronbach’s α values. The exclusion of the GS7 item is a known notion for validating this specific questionnaire
15 , 17
. As demonstrated by a Pakistani study, this item was intentionally excluded due to its perceived cultural insensitivity, resulting in trustworthy validation outcomes
15
. Moreover, a Malaysian study reported the aforementioned item as culturally offensive as perceived by the patients, hence suggesting excluding it from the social subscale in any future use of the questionnaire
16
.

The internal consistency of the FACT-G instrument, measured for each subscale, was found to be appropriate. Overall, other studies presented Cronbach’s alpha values ranging from 0.70 to 0.89
12 , 14 , 17
. The findings of our study align with previous research that has also documented good to excellent Cronbach’s alpha values ranging from 0.72 to 0.97 for the four FACT-G subscales
7 , 12 , 14 , 17 , 32
. Exceptionally, French validation performed by Conroy et al.
18
, as well as the Malay-translated version
16
, presented certain subscales with a Cronbach’s alpha lower than 0.7, such as social
16 , 18
and emotional well-being subscale
18
.

The internal consistency of the HNCS subscale was shown to be good in our study, as well as in English, Chinese, and Arabic validations
12 , 14 , 34
, ranging from 0.70 to 0.75. However, inadequate Cronbach alpha scores for HNCS subscale were noted in the Pakistani
32
, French
18
, and Malay-translated validations
17
, ranging from 0.42 to 0.52. A study conducted in Pakistan found that the low internal consistency scores of the HNCS subscale can be ascribed to certain inquiries that provide explanations in a vague manner, while other items are interpreted in reference to different subscales
32
.

The exploratory factor analysis with a non-fixed number of dimensions yielded a distinct, nine-component configuration of the FACT-HN (Supplement 1). The arrangement of the loaded components did not align with the initial hypothesized composition of the scale. Several items related to patients’ physical well-being, as well as their functioning and head and neck subscales, were observed within different domains. Hence, five of the nine identified subscales were formed with two or three items. Therefore, the practical applications of the mentioned subscales are questionable. The five-factor exploratory factor analysis corroborated the initially proposed five-component framework of the questionnaire (Supplement 2). In this specific dataset, an alternate factorial model surfaced that exhibited superior fit, indicating that specific items would be more suitably categorized into alternative subscales than initially designated.

Through a fixed-factor exploratory analysis, GP6 (“I feel ill”), GF5 (“I am sleeping well”), and HN12 (“I have pain in my mouth, throat or neck”) were assigned to the ‘‘emotional well-being’’ domain by the exploratory analysis. Even though this structure was not presented in the original questionnaire, this construction is reasonable, as how sick one feels is similar to the importance of regulating emotions and sensitivity to contextual factors
33
. The lack of sleep not only increases emotional sensitivity to stressful surroundings
34
but also leads to a decline in the ability to manage impulses and generate sentiments
35
, which are crucial aspects of cancer treatment. Furthermore, chronic pain is shown to be a significant factor in the formation of dysfunctional regulation of emotions, characterized by a tendency to focus more on adverse circumstances, which is linked to increased instances of pain
36
. Furthermore, the item GE2 (“I am satisfied with how I am coping with my illness”) was assigned to the ‘‘physical well-being’’ domain. This relationship we found is highly likely as physical health is heavily negatively influenced by the adoption of poor coping strategies, such as denial and disengagement
37
. GP1 (“I have a lack of energy”), GP3 (“Because of my physical condition, I have trouble meeting the needs of my family”), and GF4 (“I have accepted my illness”) were assigned to the “head and neck” subscale, along with items HN1-3, HN5, and HN6. In general, the above items discuss the perception of the disease itself, as well as the experience of certain physical traits and the resulting symptoms. It is important to observe that this scale primarily emphasizes the emotional and social aspects of the physical symptoms associated with head and neck malignancies. It particularly highlights the participant’s unrestricted consumption of food that they enjoy, thus emphasizing the emotional significance of the noted items. While the structure of item loading may not align with the original conceptual arrangement of the scale, the relationships we have discovered are feasible: these patients exhibit significant dietary burden while facing obstacles when it comes to accepting dietary assistance from physicians
38
; these patients often feel discouraged about the persistent treatment-related side effects preventing them from resume eating
39
; individuals with HNC suffer from physical symptoms that restrict their ability to eat normally, particularly in social situations, which is of significant concern and has an immense impact on their QoL
40
.

The confirmatory analysis substantiated the questionnaire’s structure, affirming that the items corresponded effectively with the proposed theoretical model. The results exhibited acceptable fit indices, corroborating the proposed component structure and demonstrating that the questionnaire consistently assesses the targeted constructs: physical, social, emotional, and functional well-being, along with specific symptoms in relation to the localization of the primary cancer. The instrument’s validity is strengthened as a result of this confirmation, and it guarantees that the instrument accurately captures the dimensions it was designed to evaluate.

A comparison of the instrument versus the EORTC QLQC-30 score showed a medium to strong correlation between physical, emotional, and functional factors, as well as the HNCS subscale score and the total FACT-G score. Although significant, social well-being scores presented a relatively weak correlation with an overall EORTC QLQC-30 score. This result pattern has been previously detected and attributed to the different approach and number of questions while measuring the same construct, as the FACT scale encompasses seven items, measuring specific aspects of participants’ support related to their friends, family, and partners. In contrast, the EORTC scale includes only two questions for measuring this aspect, focusing on the impact of the illness on subjects’ social aspects of everyday life
17 , 18
.

Certain EORTCHN43 segments, such as mouth pain, swallowing, dry mouth and sticky saliva, speech, social eating, sexuality, and social contact, strongly and negatively correlated to the HNCS subscales. Common oral morbidities linked to HNC treatment encompass dysphagia, xerostomia, mouth discomfort, and abnormalities in taste and smell
41
. Anatomical alterations in the pharynx and mouth cavity result in restricted range of motion and reduced movement velocity
42
. Decay in oral function, including chewing, swallowing, salivation, gustation, dental health, and speaking, may lead to other issues such as malnutrition
43
. Difficulties in mastication and deglutition hinder social dining, transforming meals into a cause of anxiety rather than pleasure, further lowering overall functioning
44
. These malignancies may also impact sexuality, diminishing closeness and self-assurance in personal interactions
45
. In general, social interaction is often highly and negatively impacted, as individuals face physical and emotional challenges caused by their condition
46
. To fully comprehend the effects of the disease on patients with HNC, it is crucial to assess and preserve oral function as well as QoL. Therefore, the patient’s functional outcomes and QoL should be considered when making treatment decisions for HNC.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The Serbian version of the FACT-HN demonstrated strong reliability and validity, making it a valuable tool for assessing QoL in Serbian-speaking HNC patients. The PRO maintained high internal consistency across all subscales, aligning well with the original version, and showed satisfactory convergent validity when compared to other well-established QoL instruments. Our findings support the utility of this translated version in capturing the multidimensional impacts of HNC on patients’ overall well-being. Further studies with larger, diverse patient populations could strengthen these findings and assess its longitudinal sensitivity to treatment-related changes in QoL.
